msDesc.head: Bede, Historia ecclesiastica; Henry of Huntingdon, Historia anglorum; Ps.-Aristotle; etc.

supportDesc.support:
Written on 264 good-quality membrane leaves preceded by one modern paper flyleaf and followed by one membrane leaf of coarser quality than elsewhere and one modern paper flyleaf. Originally two separate manuscripts.
Fore- and endleaves: fol. ir, number; fol. iv, blank; fols.Ir-IIv, blank.
supportDesc.foliation: Medieval foliation 5 to 266 on fols. 5-264; also paginated in 9th-century(?) ink.
supportDesc.collation: Collation: 1-148 156 16-248 2510 || 268 278 (2 and 7 are half-sheets), 288 2910 (wants 4, 5) 30-338. Quire signatures ai—iiij to fi—iiij remain on quires 1-6: others have probably been trimmed off.
supportDesc.condition: A quire of ten or twelve paper leaves was excised after fol. 264: a knife-slit in the old flyleaf, fol. I, which bears marks from an earlier All Souls binding (see below), shows that this was done after the book came to the College. At the bottom of fol. 264v is Finem [sic] lybri (s. xv), probably in the same hand that wrote [. . .] incipit' at the bottom of fol. 1r.

layoutDesc.layout: Both parts pricked for frame ruling and executed in crayon. Folded FSOS.

handDesc.handNote: English secretary scripts. Punctuation is by low point and double virgula.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two/three-line red initials, each with a guide letter beside it.
Rubrics, red paragraph marks, underlining, and stroking.

binding.p: Sewn on six bands between projecting bevelled medieval boards covered with white alum-tawed sheepskin (s. xviii). On the spine is a black leather lozenge-shaped label with 2 on it. Fol. I, an original flyleaf, has holes which show that the old binding was in the customary All Souls style, with a chain-plate held by six nails at the bottom of the back cover (position I) and, on the side, two catches, now missing, to hold the strap fastener. Rust on the lower board and flyleaf shows that a piece of metal from the chain-plate is still present beneath the pastedown. Edges are yellowed and there is a fore-edge title.

history.provenance:
Ker, All Souls, List II, no. 73, with Libri theologie cathenati. No. 7 in James, Ecloga, and no. 1402 (1) in CIVIA. At the top of fol. 1 is ex libris style 2, Liber Collegii Omnium Animarum fidelium Defunctorum de Oxon and at the bottom of fol. 2 ex libris style 1, Liber Collegij animarum omnium fidelium defunctorum de Oxon.
All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, on the front pastedown, vv.9. and ww:4:11 (both deleted), M.S. 31 (figure added), L.R. 2.b.13 (pencil), 108 (pencil), bookplate no. 8, and This MS. contains 264 folios. A. F. Etheridge [Sub-Librarian], 18 March 1885.; on fol.ir 6:6 (pencil). Small All Souls book stamps are on the outsides of the covers and passim.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.

altIdentifier.idno: All Souls College MS. 31, part A

msItem.incipit: Fol. 1r. Gloriosissimo regi ceolwlfo Beda famulo christi.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 1v. posteritas lateris mandare studi minus.
msItem.incipit: Posteritas occeani insula quondam albion nomen fuit.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 101vb. peruenire. et parere semper ante faciem tuam. Preterea omnes ad quos hac eadem historia peruenire potuerit
msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Historia ecclesiastica gentis anglorum

listBibl.bibl: Ed. B. Colgrave and R. A. B. Mynors (Oxford, 1969).

msItem.note: (This manuscript listed p. lvi, among copies of the common text of Southern England in the later Middle Ages). In other manuscripts Preterea omnes inueniam (edn. 6) is found at the end of the preface.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 105v. Cornelius nepos salustio crispo suo salutem... ad pollicitum reuertamur. Pelias rex in penelaponense esonem fratrem habuit.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 115rb/2. Antenorem secuti duo milia quingenti helenum mine ducenti. Quis troianorum quem grecorum occiderunt... Diomedes. antyppum [sic]. Mestem [sic].
msItem.author: Dares Phrygius
msItem.title: De excidio troiae
msItem.note: Quis troianorum is the beginning of the usual two supplementary sections, nineteen lines in all, for which see CR i. 12-13.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 115v. Britannia qui beatissima est insularum fecunda frugibus
Fol. 200ra. vt aqua in vase terebrato defluit et nil habens.
msItem.finalRubric: Hec sunt nomina regum christianorum in anglia.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 200v. migrauit ad dominum die sancti edmundi archiepiscopi et sepultus est die sancti eadmundi regis et martinis in ecclesia beati petri apud Westmonasterium.
msItem.author: Henry of Huntingdon
msItem.title: Historia Anglorum

listBibl.bibl: Ed. D. E. Greenway, Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon, Historia Anglorum (Oxford, 1996).

msItem.note: Our manuscript, Greenway's MS (O), is derived from a lost copy of Aberystwyth, National Library of Wales, Peniarth 382 (Hengwrt 101), in which the text is in seven books and ends at 1129 (edn. 252/4). For a brief description of our manuscript see her p. cxxxvii. On the confused dating of the epilogue, beginning Hic est annus and continuing qui comprehendit scriptorem annum tricesimo regni... regis Anglorum henrici annus lx. ab aduentu normannorum... annus gracie mus cus 1.xiiijus [sic]... , see edn. xlii n. 1.

collation.catchwords: Catchwords, written by the scribe, are on quires 1-24, in a cartouche.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in two columns, each 185-20560-70 C.40 lines on fols. 1-150, c.34-40 on fols. 151-200.

handDesc.handNote: English secretary script. One scribe wrote A.

altIdentifier.idno: All Souls College MS. 31, part B

msItem.incipit: Fol. 201r. Incipit liber moralium de regimine dominorum qui alio nomine dicitur secretum secretorum... [Prologue] Domino suo excellentissimo et in culto christiane religionis serenissimo [space] de Valencia ciuitatis tripolis glorioso pontifici
Fol. 202r. [Capitula] Incipit prohemium ad comendacionem Aristotelis. Deus omnipotens custodiat regem nostrum.
Secundus prologus. Johannes qui transtulit istum librum... peti-cionem in hac forma. Epistola Aristotelis missa ad petitionem. Incipit Tertius prologus. O fili carissime imperator.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 227vb. De qualitate et equalitate hominis. Ille vero est homo optime memorie bene compositus in natura ||
msItem.author: Ps.-Aristotle
msItem.title: Secretum secretorum in the version of Philippus Tripolitanus

listBibl.bibl: Ed. R. Möller, Hiltgart von Hiirnheinz, Mittelhochdeutsche Prosaübersetzung des 'Secretum Secretorum' (Berlin 1963), 1-164.
On the text and for references see PAL, no. 81.

msItem.note: Because of the excision of two leaves the text ends incomplete in ch. 76, edn. 164/50, with the loss of thirteen lines of printed text.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 228r. || speculetur attencione... Finito prologo incipit liber de morte Aristotelis. Cum clausa esset via veritatis.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 231v. et perfecti sicut to es. Explicit liber de morte Aristotelis siue de pomo.
msItem.author: Ps.-Aristotle
msItem.title: De pomo sive de morte Aristotelis

listBibl.bibl: Ed. M. Plezia, Aristotelis qui ferebatur liber de pomo (Warsaw, 1960).
On the text see PAL, no. 75.

msItem.note: Due to the loss of two leaves in the previous quire, thirty lines of printed text are lost from the beginning, before edn. 39/2.

msItem.title: Three Aristotle texts in the 'Nova translatio' attributed to Willelmus de Moerbeke

msItem.incipit: Fol. 232r. Incipit liber de longitudine et breuitate vite Aristotelis. De eo autem quod est hec quidem esse longe vite animalium
msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: De longitudine et brevitate vitae
msItem.note: AL i. 142b-143b, printed from beginning to MS fol. 232ra/42 causa aliis and from fol. 233rb/27 In animalibus to end. A tentative conclusion that the translation of De longitudine et brevitate is by Moerbeke is reached by J. Judycka, 'L'Attribution de la Translatio nova du De generatione et corruptione a Guillaume de Moerbeke', in Guillaume de Moerbeke: Recueil d'itudes a. l'occasion rlu poe anniversaire de sa mort (1286) , ed. J. Brams and W. Vanhamel (Ancient and Medieval Philosophy, De Wulf-Mansion Centre, Series I, 7; Louvain, 1989), 247-51.

msItem.incipit: [In margin de iuuentute et senectute] De iuuentute et senectute et vita et morte
msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: De iuventute et senectute
msItem.note: AL i. 144b-145b, printed from beginning to MS fol. 233va/41 dimittunt primo and from fol. 234vb/20 Ieiunia autem to end.

msItem.incipit: Incipit liber de morte et vita. [Fol. 235r/] Est quidem igitur animalibus commune generatione et mors
msItem.explicit: Fol. 236ra. de vita quidem igitur de morte et de cognati huius speculacionis. fere dictum est de omnibus. Explicit de morte et vita.
msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: De morte et vita
msItem.note: AL i. 147b-148b, printed from beginning to MS fol. 235rb/10 fit omnino and from fol. 235vb/42 Eleuato quidem to end.

msItem.rubric: Fol. 236r. Incipit prologus In philobiblon Ricardi dunolmensis Episcopi
msItem.incipit: Vniuersis christi fidelibus ad quos tenor scripture presentis peruenerit
msItem.finalRubric: Fol. 237r. Explicit prologus incipiunt Capitula libri... Expliciunt Capitula.
msItem.rubric: Quod Thesaurus sapiencie potestissiime sit in libris Capitulum primum
msItem.explicit: Fol. 254v. perpetuum fruibilis faciei conspectum amen.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit tractatus qui dicitur Philobiblon idest amor librorum editus a domino Ricardo de Bun quondam Dunelm' Episcopo Completus est autem in manerio nostro de Akeland in festo conuercionis Sancti Pauli Anno domini ml CCCmo xliiijo etatis nostrelviijo Pontificatus vero nostri Anno xjo finiente ad laudem dei feliciter Amen.
msItem.author: Richard Aungervyle of Bury
msItem.title: Philobiblon

listBibl.bibl: For this manuscript (Sl) see pp. 31-2 (with minor misreadings of colophon evidently derived from edition by E. C. Thomas (London, 1888), re-edited with foreword by M. Maclagan (Oxford, 1960)).

msItem.incipit: Fol. 255r. Rumwaldus archiepiscopus ut capille nascantur. Panem ordeaceum et cartam cum sale equaliter
msItem.explicit: Fol. 264v. Ad lentiginem in facie. Piper saponem album... unguentum ||
msItem.title: An unidentified series of medical recipes, perhaps the beginning of a 'head-to-foot' collection.
msItem.note: Recipes concern, inter alia, the hair, headache, madness, melancholy, the eyes, ears, teeth, and catarrh. Rumwaldus presumably refers to Romwaldus, possibly abp. of Salerno, d. 1181, on whom see Renzi, iv. 569-73; Manitius, iii. 331-2. On this identification see B. Lawn, The Salernitan Questions (Oxford, 1963), 70—1.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in two columns, each 185-20560-70 C.36-40 lines.

handDesc.handNote: English secretary script. One scribe wrote fols. 201r-236ra and probably a second scribe (but the hand is variable and there could be a third scribe) from fol. 236rb to the end.
